title: Johnny Weekly
text:
John Weekly (June 14, 1937 – November 24, 1974) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a> whose career extended from 1956 through 1965. The <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> appeared in 53 <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League</a> <a href="games%20played">games</a> for the <a href="Houston%20Colt%20.45s">Houston Colt .45s</a> from to . Weekly batted and threw <a href="right-handed">right-handed</a>; he stood tall and weighed .
He was born in <a href="Waterproof%2C%20Louisiana">Waterproof</a> in <a href="Tensas%20Parish%2C%20Louisiana">Tensas Parish</a>, <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, but graduated from high school in <a href="Pittsburg%2C%20California">Pittsburg</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, and attended <a href="Diablo%20Valley%20College">Diablo Valley College</a> in <a href="Pleasant%20Hill%2C%20California">Pleasant Hill</a>, California. His career began in the <a href="New%20York%20Giants%20%28NL%29">New York Giants</a>' organization, but was never called up by the MLB Giants, who moved to Weekly's home <a href="San%20Francisco%20Bay%20Area">San Francisco Bay Area</a> in 1958. Instead, he was selected in the 1961 <a href="Rule%205%20draft">Rule 5 draft</a> by <a href="expansion%20team">expansion team</a> Houston, set to enter the Majors in . Weekly's big-league debut came in the Colt .45s fourth-ever game, on April 13. He <a href="ground%20ball">grounded out</a> to the <a href="second%20baseman">second baseman</a> as a <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hitter</a> off <a href="Jack%20Hamilton%20%28baseball%29">Jack Hamilton</a> of the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> in the ninth <a href="inning%20%28baseball%29">inning</a> of a 3–2 defeat at <a href="Connie%20Mack%20Stadium">Connie Mack Stadium</a>. Six days later, he collected his first MLB <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a>: a solo <a href="home%20run">home run</a> off the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a>' <a href="Don%20Cardwell">Don Cardwell</a> in a 6-0 Houston triumph at <a href="Wrigley%20Field">Wrigley Field</a>. Weekly was returned to the Giants' system in mid-May after starting five games in the <a href="outfield">outfield</a> and 13 total appearances; his five hits included three <a href="extra-base%20hit">extra-base</a> blows, among them his second big-league homer (off <a href="Pete%20Richert">Pete Richert</a> of the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a>) on May 7.
After finishing 1962 with the <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> <a href="Tacoma%20Giants">Tacoma Giants</a>, he was reacquired by Houston and assigned to the Triple-A <a href="Oklahoma%20City%2089ers">Oklahoma City 89ers</a>, where he had his finest <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league</a> season in , <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting</a> .363 with 86 hits in 67 games. That earned him a promotion to the Colt .45s in midseason for a 34-game stint. Weekly batted .225 with three home runs and 18 hits. His high-water mark came September 18, with three extra base hits in five <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a> against the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a>, including two <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">doubles</a> off Cincinnati fireballer <a href="Jim%20Maloney">Jim Maloney</a>. He drove in four <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs</a> and hit his fifth and final big-league homer off the Reds' <a href="Dom%20Zanni">Dom Zanni</a>.
Weekly made the Houston roster coming out of <a href="spring%20training">spring training</a> in , but made only two hits in 15 at bats and returned to Oklahoma City. On June 15, he was traded to the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a>, but logged only nine games for the Orioles' Triple-A affiliate before returning to the Houston organization. After one more full year with the 89ers, in 1965, Weekly left professional baseball. He died from injuries sustained in a road accident in <a href="Walnut%20Creek%2C%20California">Walnut Creek, California</a> on November 24, 1974.
